segments.text: apartment did you have any rugs no bare floors what about throw rugs what about curtains well curtains we made out of i made them out of sheets you know just cut them up that i think the color sheets came up or did my mother dye those i don't remember i know she gave us curtains for the kitchen
And I made the others for the bedrooms.
And we just did improvise with whatever we could.
And the kitchen stove, how many burners?
I think there were four burners, but it was a small stove.
But it had an oven.
Uh-huh.
And your washing machine.

yeah i had i had a washing machine that we had that was ours an old roller yeah but did it have rinse tubs or did you use the no we used to sink they had deep sinks i guess that's why they built them and then the you had a solar a solar dryer out in the sun yes you had to hang the clothes out in the sun where did where did what advice did any of your neighbor friends give you as you moved in did any of them
Well, just said that we had to be patient and loving and says, don't fuss at your husband and try to make it easy.
And we tried to help each other and talk to each other about that.
And one of the funniest things, they laugh about the introduction I had.
When they came to welcome me and all of that, it was late in the evening and I had put some cabbage on to cook.
And I think I turned the fire low.
But anyway, we went out and sat on the grass, and pretty soon we started smelling.
Oh, what's burning, and what's burning, and what's burning?
And even the students that were coming kind of late from the library, it was a burn.
And then all of a sudden, down on me, I think it's my cabbage.
I ran in there, and they said, oh, what an introduction to the neighborhood.
I stunk about.
And almost all of the other couples were veterans.
Were veterans.
And did most of them have children?
Yes.
Helen, the Darings had one, and the Cantrells had one.
Lippincott had one.
And we had one, which we were the closest one.
Of course, back of us lived Peter.
I can't think of their last name.
But anyway, he came and played with
Robert was so funny.
That wall was so thin that at night Peter used to wake up and say, Mama, Mama, and I'd jump out and go in to see about Robert and he'd be sound asleep.
But we could hear everything.
Coming through the wall.
Did you all begin to share things?
Oh yes.
We had to, mostly the, Francis and Cantrell and Buddy, we became good close friends, very close friends.
And Francis' cousin, Yay Larry, first cousin, was a football player and a baseball player.
That's how we got in the games.
And he liked Mexican food.
So my mother would send us corn tortillas and she'd send us care packages, corn tortillas and beans and rice.
And so, and then one time that I went home I brought the chili
the red chili to make enchiladas.
And ground meat was what we could afford.
So we made it with peas and corn and potatoes, anything we could put together.
About every two weeks, Francis and I, we would fix a Mexican supper and we would have Ye Larry and my brother Carlos, who was in school here, come over and eat with us.
And we had enchiladas and rice and beans.
But we, of course, iced tea and we had a good time.
And like I said, that's the way we got into football games and baseball games because.
All right, describe your impression when you first went to an Aggie football game.
Well, I had been before because my brothers were here.
At that time, when we came to football games, I may have been in elementary school when my brother was here, or in junior high, when my first brother was here.
He graduated in 39.
They did all of this yelling and all of that.
They never sat down.
So when Ralph came, I was already used to all of that.
Now where did, when you all went to the games as a married couple, where did, were you over in the student section?
Uh huh.
And did you take Robert with you?
Yes.
And you stood up?
We stood up.
And did married folks kiss after Aggie touchdowns?
Oh yes.
Yes.
Do you remember any incidents, any special moments during that first football season?
No, let's see, I forget who was the quarterback.
Was it Bob Smith?
No, he was a good running back.
Glenn Lippman.
Glenn Lippman was a, uh-huh.
From where was he from?
Anyway, all of those, and C.J.
Larry was a running back.
And we got the tickets and we'd go, you know, Francis and myself and Ralph and Buddy and Carl, the little boy, and Robert, our son.
And I don't know whether Ralph showed you the pictures of Carl and Robert.
We'd go to the games.
And then when Eisenhower was here,
That's Robert.
Oh, how good, how good.
That's splendid.
That was in 1951 when he was here.
And this is Carl.
And see, there's Bonnie Lippincott and Robert and, no, that's Susan Darin.
Bonnie Lippincott, Susan Darin, Robert and Carl.
Eisenhower was here.
Now what was the purpose of his visit?
He was a general and they had...
So he came...
Yes.
This is before he was politicking.
Yes.
He came here as a general.
And it was cold.
It must have been in February.
I don't have a date because this was out of the Houston Post.
I didn't cut out the date or the...
And did you go to see Eisenhower?
Yeah, it was in the drill field.
The Corps was in review for him, and he was in the reviewing stand.
What was your impression of him, of Eisenhower?
Oh, I liked him.
I thought he was just a great man.
During that first year, what was a typical, describe a typical class day routine for you and your husband?
You all got up about what time?
Well, we got up about 6.30 or 7, because Ralph had to be in class by 8, and got up and fixed his breakfast, and he got ready and left.
What was a normal breakfast?
Oh, a normal breakfast, then we could get pullet eggs.
And my mother sometimes would send us bacon.
And it was just really toast and eggs.
And I got my mother, every time we went, because she'd send us a lot of jelly and stuff that we had.
And that was it, and coffee.
Or sometimes we had cereal.
And then when Robert got up, he always had oatmeal.
and I would feed him and I would eat with him.
And then Ralph would be off to class by eight.
Before eight, because he had classes at eight o'clock.
And either we stayed there and Robert would go on and play with all the kids.
They played by the side of the house.
And we'd just kind of watch them and
we had anything to do, well, we'd get done.
And then it was time for him to take a nap.
Of course, Ralph would come home for lunch.
And if he had classes or a lab in the afternoon, he would go.
And if not, he'd go to the library and study.
And he would study at home.
And so we had to be quiet while they were studying.
And we just tried to
keep each other company, the wives.
Then it was time for supper, and we had our supper, and then the kids played a little bit, and we'd sit around watching them play, and the men would be studying.
Time to go to bed, and then the next day was the same routine.
What did you women do to relax?
Well, I guess we took naps.
We played cards.

um and that was about it we just kind of visited with each other and played cards and and took naps and we helped out when we if one was sick or something we tried to help each other because everybody was equally poor yes everybody was getting the same paycheck there were a few that were getting help from home maybe almost all on the gi bill oh yes
And rent was $30?
Did that include utilities?
Everything.
$30 included the refrigerator and the stove and the utilities.
Oh, I forgot.
Describe the air conditioning system.
Oh, we didn't have one.
The windows were where you could get a stick and go outside and pull that flap up.
and you know, tied up.
Of course it had the screen, but that was, we did have a fan that my mother gave us, but that was all.
No air conditioning.
So you had one fan?
Mm-hmm.
So you could use it?
In the kitchen or the hallway and then in the bedroom.
Right.
Then let's make believe that on a Saturday night you all wanted to do something kind of special for entertainment.
What would you do?
I think we may have gone to maybe some picture shows, some movies, because we could go to Guyon for 25 cents or 15 cents.
And that's how we got acquainted with Mr. Putty.
And at the end of the sophomore year when we were in Vet Village,
Ralph had gone all over the college looking for a part-time job and couldn't get one because we were getting the money.

And so Mr. Putty, no, one of the boys or something, one of the students that worked there was going summer camp or something, and he taught Ralph how to do the projector, and Mr. Putty helped him out.
And so when he had somebody out, he would call on Ralph.
to do that and I think he did that the last two months, April and May of the sophomore year when we were here.
And then at the end of May, Mr. Smith called him or wrote to him and told him that he would like for him to come and take a summer job so his employees could go on vacation and he trusted Ralph
take over.
So we gave up the apartment and we stored the furniture, I believe.
And we moved to
to San Antonio and got a little efficiency place and he worked and of course we saved the money.
And then we tried to get back into Vet Village.
They were getting ready to tear that down.
So they assigned us to College View.
And we moved into College View and his uncle had given him a refrigerator.
So we brought our own refrigerator.
And we set up in College View, we had Lewis and Margaret Springer for our neighbors, and Wallace and Irene Larson.
They were veterinary students, but we got real close with them.
And the Beige, Helen Beige and her husband.
And she had an automatic washing machine.
her family had given her an automatic washing machine and by that time I had started working at Guyon Hall.
So I had a little bit of money and she would do my laundry for 25 cents a load.
But it still had to be hung out.
So she would do the laundry and I would hang it out because I didn't come to work till about one o'clock.
The theater wasn't open till then.
So I came to work at one.
So she would do the laundry and I'd hang it up, and then she would bring it in, because I worked till five o'clock, and if somebody wanted to use the line or the clothes were dry, we had to.
So you worked every afternoon?
Every afternoon.
What was your pay, do you remember?
I think I got like 60 cents an hour.
And what was your task?
I was the ticket, sold the tickets, the ticket sales lady.
So afternoon, not in the evening though?
No, in the afternoon.
We were two.
One week I worked the evening from 1 to 5, and then the other would work from 5 on.
And then the next week we'd switch.
I would come in at 5 and she'd come in at 1, so that we had the same thing.
Who took care of Robert while you were?
Well, we had a lady in the next barrack that did babysitting.
And she kept Robert until Ralph got home.
And then, of course, when Ralph was a senior was when Robert started school.
We had to pay for him to go to school because he wasn't quite six.
And he started at A&M Consolidated.
And at that time, I was having trouble with hemorrhoids.
And of course, we'd go home to Dr. Langster.
Every time we went home, he'd check us over, all three of us, and gave us medication or samples or whatever we needed.
So I went to him.
It was before Thanksgiving.
And in one of the hemorrhoids, I had a little growth.
And he was very concerned.
And he said, I know it's going to be a hardship on you all.
And, but he says, I need to do the surgery right away, as soon as we can, because he didn't want, you know, anything to happen, or he was concerned.
So we moved out of College View in November of 52, and I went back to Beeville.
And we stored our furniture.
My dad had built two bedrooms onto the garage and a bathroom, but we weren't using one.
I think two of my brothers were still at home.
They were in high school, and they slept in one of the bedrooms.
So we stored our furniture there and moved in with mother.
And I had surgery.
Dr. Langston said, let's wait until after Christmas.
So I think I had surgery in January of 53.
And I got well, and of course I went to work for my dad.
I mean, I worked for dad in the office to help him out until Ralph graduated.
Now did you take Robert home with you?
Yes, I took Robert home.
He had started at A&M Consolidated, but then I took him home and he went to school in Burklair with my sister.
My sister was teaching there.
So he went to school in Burklair his first year.
Well, he went here until November and then the rest of the year he went.
All right, during the years that you were here, describe shopping in Bryan College Station.
Where'd you go grocery shopping?
We went to Safeway and to the Atlantic store, whichever had the, we'd watch the sales, each one of them.
We'd get together, the wives get together, oh, this is on sale at Atlantic, this is on sale at Safeway.
So really what we got was staples, coffee, rice, beans, vermicelli.
And they were both downtown?
Downtown, uh-huh.
And we'd go into Bryan and buy, and really, clothes, whenever I went to Beeville, my mother would, you know, we'd go buy clothes there.
And my brother in Puerto Rico had, he and his father-in-law had shoe stores all over the island.
So he would send me some name brand shoes.
Of course, they don't have this narrow size, and I wear a,
triple toe and quite him.
But he would send the name brand, maybe in a B, but he said, take them to the store and he'd write, and they will exchange them.
And they did that.
So he would send me the shoe and he would send Ralph and Robert shoes, of course they could wear them.
But I couldn't wear mine, but he would send the name brand, and I'd take them into a shoe store in Bryan.
Where, if you needed something quickly, some kind of groceries, was there any?
We went to the, well, when we were here, we went to the little store on.
The corner of what is now University in Texas?
Well, no, that was when we lived in Collegeview.
But there was one up here.
You know where Brothers are?
Right in that area, what was the name of that little grocery store?
There was a barber shop.
Oh, you're saying at Southgate?
Yeah, Southgate.
No, is it Southgate?
Yes, yes, Southgate.
That's where the Little Grocery Store.
And if we needed something, we'd run over there and get it.
When we were in College View, we went to the Little Grocery Store and if we ran out of something and last week we had to have something, we could charge it.
And then at the first of the month, he knew that at the first of the month all the veterans got paid.
But we learned to cook the ground meat with everything.
And, of course, sometimes we would get chicken because they would sell the chickens here, well, reasonable.
Now, you said you went to the Baptist church.
You mentioned that you had, did you grow up a Methodist?
No, I grew up a Catholic.
You grew up Catholic.
What about Ralph?
Catholic.
Okay.
Why Baptist?
Well, when I went to live with Miss Hall,
He was a Baptist deacon and she was a Sunday school teacher in the Baptist church.
And they knew I came from a Catholic.
They never did ask me or anything, but I would ask them if I could go with them.
So I really wasn't
The reason we were not strong or devout Catholics was because my mother married my father who was a Methodist.
Those Methodist missionaries, his mother and father were Methodists, and of course my father and his sisters were Methodists.
And my mother married a Methodist.
So when she married him, she was excommunicated from the Catholic Church.
And it hurt my grandfather and grandmother very much because my grandfather had built that Catholic church in Berkeley and he was such a devout Catholic and so was my grandmother.
The priest ate at her house on Sundays when he'd go in from Goliad to Berkeley for Mass.
But my mother could not practice her religion.
But my grandfather and grandmother, being devout Catholics, they would baptize.
My father didn't object because we lived next door to them.
But we were not given the Catholic training like catechism and all of that.
And so actually, when I went to live, we'd go to Mass.
We'd go to, we never did go to the catechism classes.
But my grandfather, in his last five years of life, he had houses for rent there in Berkeley.

and there was this missionary that came from the Assembly of God and established a little church there with some families that were dissatisfied with the priest and they were big families like they had nine kids and there were four families and each with nine or ten kids so that made a good congregation and my and he
I talked to my grandfather for a long time.
My grandfather was converted into the Assembly of God Church about four years before he died.
And my grandmother kept on being a good Catholic, but because of his memory, it was so funny, she'd take us to Mass and then at 9.45 we'd go to Sunday school at the Assembly of God Church.
And that's how I got that
Training.
So when you all came here.
We were both, I had joined the Baptist Church like in 1940.
Oh, okay, so you were.
You already were a Baptist.
Uh-huh.
Okay.
And when I married Ralph, we married in the Baptist Church, and then we dedicated Robert in the Baptist Church, and then he joined about a year later.
Describe this congregation and what it was like to be a young married couple in the First Baptist Church.
Well, there were a lot of student members there, and I can't think of Dr. Richardson.
Well, Dr. Brown was the minister there, but they had gotten a new one because there was so much controversy.
They had been kind of like dissatisfied with it.
But I think it was Dr. Rich that was the pastor then, and his wife taught a Sunday school class of young women that were, most of them were students.
So I joined that class, and Ralph joined a class, and of course Robert was in Sunday school.
And Ralph was an usher, and sometimes I helped in the nursery.
And we just had, I mean, we enjoyed.
We couldn't wait to Sunday to go to Sunday school.
And Dr. Berry was the superintendent of the Sunday schools.
I can remember him very well.
Miss Pugh was Robert's Sunday School class teacher.
Mrs. Marion Pugh.
Marion Pugh's wife.
And then the summer of 52,
We didn't go to San Antonio, Ralph State to go to summer school, and I helped with the Vacation Mile School.
I helped Miss Pugh with the Vacation Mile School.
And I remember we had Coach, Gail, Stanky's twins in there, and they were horrible.
And that's about what we did, but in our family, my father wouldn't,
object to us being whatever.
Because I have a brother that's Episcopalian.
I have two brothers that are Presbyterians.
I have a brother that's a Baptist.
And I think only two are Catholic.
No, just one is Catholic.
Did anyone ever tease you being Hispanic and Baptist?
Did anybody ever?
Well they were all surprised and they still are.
You know I'm the librarian in a little Catholic school.
Of course, they have changed a lot.
I mean, they don't go to confession anymore and they don't do a lot of things.
And like I told Sister, I said, it looks like I'm sitting in a Baptist church.
But when I went there and the other teachers found out I was Baptist, did you become a Baptist?
What were your parents, you know?
And when I tell them about the recent experience,
we weren't brought up as devout Catholic was because of my mother being excommunicated from the Catholic Church.
Of course, they don't do that now, but at that time.
Now, I haven't sensed in anything you've said anybody teasing or doing anything negative that you were Hispanic.
No.
That you were fully accepted everywhere.
No.
And as y'all are living in Vet Village and in College View, did y'all ever think about stopping and going back to San Antonio?
No.
So you never looked back?
No.
Were there any semesters when the grades were marginal?
Oh, yes.
Is that right?
And sometimes, you know, I knew he was having a hard time because I had, you know, gone through junior college and then University of Mexico, and I knew how hard it was.
And I knew he was worried about his grandmother because she died when we were living at Bed Village, and she raised him.
And thinking about his mother and not being in school for so long.
I knew it was going to be a struggle for him, but I don't think I ever complained about his grades.
And he didn't flunk anything?
No.
No, he didn't flunk anything.
And he told me about changing his major to marketing.
Did he discuss that with you?
Yes.
And you endorsed the...
The wives had talked about, you know, we need to support our husbands.
They've been through a war.
They've been, some of them, you know, had had a hard life.
They had to work when they were kids and all of that.
So we just figured that we talked about it.
We have to support them in whatever endeavor.
I mean, if they want to change their majors or maybe they want to stay an extra year.

so and uh just about every one of the couples were first generation college students all short of money uh some from small towns but some from the city city almost all were texans i yes i think so all of our neighbors i think were from texas now
We did have a neighbor way down the street, and she and I became friends because she was from Canada.
And she was a little bit, she dressed a little bit different than we did.
She spoke a little bit different, and she was kind of chubby.
And I don't know why she was comfortable with me, but she'd come to the house and visit with me.
Now, she didn't socialize.
And even when her mother was visiting her here,
she would bring her mother and we'd visit.
And I wish I had kept their name, but they were there, just lived one year, and they moved.
But he had met her in Canada when he was in the service.
And there weren't any special social events for student wives?
No.
Well, there were some at the YMCA that you could do, but we never did  I never did go.
down there, you could go there for, now we did have, my Sunday school class had meetings at night.
Oh, okay.
You know, and I'd go to those.
The WMU.
